sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel							                                                                    															The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel										 				Courtesy New York Times.															April 10, 2019					Rick Edmonds								                    													Category: 					Business & Work										                  A year ago, without ceremony, The New York Times piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. âProject Feelsâ has now generated 50 campaigns, more than 30 million impressions and strong revenue results (the Times declines to specify how much).So itâs a hit, and the sort of advertising innovation based on data science, artificial intelligence and algorithm that the Times expects to scale up â and that other news organizations are exploring.To take an example of what the Times more formally is calling âperspective targeting,â  an interview/profile of Cher was determined to put the reader into an inspired, amused and adventurous mood. Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.  Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement.  Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.At a glance this may sound a bit manipulative and âBrave New Worldâ-like to consumers of news.Journalists and other news purists may also wonder whether the Times newsroom is now being tasked with producing lots of emotional stories.Neither is the case, Allison Murphy, senior vice president of advertising innovation, told me in an interview.  The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow. So it has done nothing different. The ad sales initiative  âdoesnât influence what is coveredâ and editorial integrity is not compromised.<img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-656513" class="size-medium wp-image-656513" src="https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=225%2C300&ssl=1" alt="" width="225" height="300" srcset="https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=225%2C300&ssl=1 225w, https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=768%2C1024&ssl=1 768w, https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=1125%2C1500&ssl=1 1125w, https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=600%2C800&ssl=1 600w, https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=75%2C100&ssl=1 75w, https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=245%2C327&ssl=1 245w, https://i2.wp.com/www.poynter.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/NYTCO-2018-crDamon Winter-Allison Murphy-Headshot.jpg?resize=447%2C596&ssl=1 447w" sizes="(max-width: 225px) 100vw, 225px" data-recalc-dims="1" />Allison Murphy. (Courtesy The New York Times)And the âProject Feelsâ ads are actually less intrusive, she argues, since they do not depend on the sort of information about you and your preferences that cookies harvest.Together, Murphy said, the two kinds of âFeelsâ targeting are a match to rising privacy concerns.  They also provide âan original type of brand safetyâ at a time when advertisers need to worry about landing next to objectionable content on platforms like YouTube or Facebook.To date, the most popular advertiser categories have been entertainment and corporate social responsibility messages. The first of the Feels sales was to a story evoking âadventurousâ and aligned with a clientâs launch of a new science fiction series. âSelf-confidentâ was paired with a message centered on womenâs empowerment.  Ads to date have also appeared across 10 other categories.Of the 18 available emotions, 14 are positive.  But even negatives like sadness or indignation, Murphy said, could support a given cause or candidate.  âBoredomâ isnât and wonât be much of a seller. Hereâs the list:Optimistic Inspired Self-Confident Amused Adventurous In the mood to spend Love Sadness Boredom Interest Fear Hate Hope Happiness Nostalgic Indulgent Competitive Informed I asked whether Project Feels might be exported as a franchised service to other news organizations.âGenerally no,â Murphy replied. âThe whole model is based on Times content, and it requires maintenance. â¦ We are very fortunate to have the resources to invest in this sort of innovation.â  That includes both âthe breadth of our content,â she added, and the sophistication to do a rigorous measure of what works and how well.However, other organizations are already playing in the same sandbox and more will follow. A Digiday story on Project Feels last summer noted that ESPN can target ads depending on whether a given fanâs team is winning or losing. USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)									                                                                                                    Comments                                                                                Comments are closed.                                                                                                                            I havenât seen an advertisement on the NYT in years, they canât track me and I have all their shenanigans blocked.  Funny, how the Poynter person cozily chats with the NYT privacy-buster-in-chief as if itâs a yawner that websites ruthlessly bust privacy and sell personal information, as if itâs all in a dayâs work.  Seems to me the âresponsible journalismâ touted here would dictate Poynter inform Little People how to evade the privacy-busters, rather than get us used to the idea we have no privacy leftâ¦                                                                                                            Chris Long                                                    April 10, 2019 at 1:18 PM,                                                                                                                                                            I am with Next Digital, we are Hong Kong and Taiwanâs largest newspaper/online media group.  (feel free to check AC Nielsen, Comscore, Alexa).  The journalism being driven by these new subscription techniques is what I call âSubscription Journalismâ.  We write for the subscribers.  NYT is the best I have seen and knows their prospective subscriber better than most.  And we should not be arrogant about this development.  Ailes at FOX pioneered then MSNBC followed and CNN is a poor second.  In online and Print we have HUFFPOST, VICE, VOX, Daily Beast, and also Daily Caller, Hot Air, Drudge.   No one needs to win it all, but rather there needs to be a set niche.  NYT with 5 million subscribers lives forever.   Yet, lets call it for it what it is.  NYT has many disappointed left leaning readers after Mueller, and maybe a few prizes that need to be returned.  But do they correct course and move on?  I would say no.  Stay with what the audience wants, which is trying to deliver Trumpâs scalp. Subscription journalism is the new norm.  We write for an audience that will pay. html.textContent: Media News Reporting & Editing Fact-Checking Ethics & Trust Tech & Tools Business & Work Educators & Students Media Jobs Newsletters Training & Events at Poynter Regional Programs Bring Poynter to You Community Events Support UsAbout Mission & Vision Our People Building & Location Office Space & Event Rentals History Ethics Policy Funders International Fact-Checking Network News Releases Contact UsNews U Login/Register Back Poynter Media News Training & Events Support About Log In / Log Out Reporting & Editing Fact-Checking Ethics & Trust Tech & Tools Business & Work Media Jobs Educators & Students Training at Poynter Regional Programs Bring Poynter to You Community Events Mission & Vision Our People History Building & Location Office Space & Event Rentals History Ethics Policy Funders International Fact-checking Network News Releases Contact Us Home Business & Work The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel Courtesy New York Times. April 10, 2019 Rick Edmonds Category: Business & Work A year ago, without ceremony, The New York Times piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. âProject Feelsâ has now generated 50 campaigns, more than 30 million impressions and strong revenue results (the Times declines to specify how much).So itâs a hit, and the sort of advertising innovation based on data science, artificial intelligence and algorithm that the Times expects to scale up â and that other news organizations are exploring.To take an example of what the Times more formally is calling âperspective targeting,â  an interview/profile of Cher was determined to put the reader into an inspired, amused and adventurous mood. Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.  Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement.  Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.At a glance this may sound a bit manipulative and âBrave New Worldâ-like to consumers of news.Journalists and other news purists may also wonder whether the Times newsroom is now being tasked with producing lots of emotional stories.Neither is the case, Allison Murphy, senior vice president of advertising innovation, told me in an interview.  The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow. So it has done nothing different. The ad sales initiative  âdoesnât influence what is coveredâ and editorial integrity is not compromised.Allison Murphy. (Courtesy The New York Times)And the âProject Feelsâ ads are actually less intrusive, she argues, since they do not depend on the sort of information about you and your preferences that cookies harvest.Together, Murphy said, the two kinds of âFeelsâ targeting are a match to rising privacy concerns.  They also provide âan original type of brand safetyâ at a time when advertisers need to worry about landing next to objectionable content on platforms like YouTube or Facebook.To date, the most popular advertiser categories have been entertainment and corporate social responsibility messages. The first of the Feels sales was to a story evoking âadventurousâ and aligned with a clientâs launch of a new science fiction series. âSelf-confidentâ was paired with a message centered on womenâs empowerment.  Ads to date have also appeared across 10 other categories.Of the 18 available emotions, 14 are positive.  But even negatives like sadness or indignation, Murphy said, could support a given cause or candidate.  âBoredomâ isnât and wonât be much of a seller. Hereâs the list:Optimistic Inspired Self-Confident Amused Adventurous In the mood to spend Love Sadness Boredom Interest Fear Hate Hope Happiness Nostalgic Indulgent Competitive Informed I asked whether Project Feels might be exported as a franchised service to other news organizations.âGenerally no,â Murphy replied. âThe whole model is based on Times content, and it requires maintenance. â¦ We are very fortunate to have the resources to invest in this sort of innovation.â  That includes both âthe breadth of our content,â she added, and the sophistication to do a rigorous measure of what works and how well.However, other organizations are already playing in the same sandbox and more will follow. A Digiday story on Project Feels last summer noted that ESPN can target ads depending on whether a given fanâs team is winning or losing. USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window) Comments Comments are closed. I havenât seen an advertisement on the NYT in years, they canât track me and I have all their shenanigans blocked. Funny, how the Poynter person cozily chats with the NYT privacy-buster-in-chief as if itâs a yawner that websites ruthlessly bust privacy and sell personal information, as if itâs all in a dayâs work. Seems to me the âresponsible journalismâ touted here would dictate Poynter inform Little People how to evade the privacy-busters, rather than get us used to the idea we have no privacy leftâ¦ Chris Long April 10, 2019 at 1:18 PM, I am with Next Digital, we are Hong Kong and Taiwanâs largest newspaper/online media group. (feel free to check AC Nielsen, Comscore, Alexa). The journalism being driven by these new subscription techniques is what I call âSubscription Journalismâ. We write for the subscribers. NYT is the best I have seen and knows their prospective subscriber better than most. And we should not be arrogant about this development. Ailes at FOX pioneered then MSNBC followed and CNN is a poor second. In online and Print we have HUFFPOST, VICE, VOX, Daily Beast, and also Daily Caller, Hot Air, Drudge. No one needs to win it all, but rather there needs to be a set niche. NYT with 5 million subscribers lives forever. Yet, lets call it for it what it is. NYT has many disappointed left leaning readers after Mueller, and maybe a few prizes that need to be returned. But do they correct course and move on? I would say no. Stay with what the audience wants, which is trying to deliver Trumpâs scalp. Subscription journalism is the new norm. We write for an audience that will pay. Mark Simon April 10, 2019 at 11:11 PM, â All Rights Reserved Poynter Institute 2019 | Privacy Policy

html.textContent: Home Business & Work The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel Courtesy New York Times. April 10, 2019 Rick Edmonds Category: Business & Work A year ago, without ceremony, The New York Times piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. âProject Feelsâ has now generated 50 campaigns, more than 30 million impressions and strong revenue results (the Times declines to specify how much).So itâs a hit, and the sort of advertising innovation based on data science, artificial intelligence and algorithm that the Times expects to scale up â and that other news organizations are exploring.To take an example of what the Times more formally is calling âperspective targeting,â  an interview/profile of Cher was determined to put the reader into an inspired, amused and adventurous mood. Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.  Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement.  Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.At a glance this may sound a bit manipulative and âBrave New Worldâ-like to consumers of news.Journalists and other news purists may also wonder whether the Times newsroom is now being tasked with producing lots of emotional stories.Neither is the case, Allison Murphy, senior vice president of advertising innovation, told me in an interview.  The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow. So it has done nothing different. The ad sales initiative  âdoesnât influence what is coveredâ and editorial integrity is not compromised.Allison Murphy. (Courtesy The New York Times)And the âProject Feelsâ ads are actually less intrusive, she argues, since they do not depend on the sort of information about you and your preferences that cookies harvest.Together, Murphy said, the two kinds of âFeelsâ targeting are a match to rising privacy concerns.  They also provide âan original type of brand safetyâ at a time when advertisers need to worry about landing next to objectionable content on platforms like YouTube or Facebook.To date, the most popular advertiser categories have been entertainment and corporate social responsibility messages. The first of the Feels sales was to a story evoking âadventurousâ and aligned with a clientâs launch of a new science fiction series. âSelf-confidentâ was paired with a message centered on womenâs empowerment.  Ads to date have also appeared across 10 other categories.Of the 18 available emotions, 14 are positive.  But even negatives like sadness or indignation, Murphy said, could support a given cause or candidate.  âBoredomâ isnât and wonât be much of a seller. Hereâs the list:Optimistic Inspired Self-Confident Amused Adventurous In the mood to spend Love Sadness Boredom Interest Fear Hate Hope Happiness Nostalgic Indulgent Competitive Informed I asked whether Project Feels might be exported as a franchised service to other news organizations.âGenerally no,â Murphy replied. âThe whole model is based on Times content, and it requires maintenance. â¦ We are very fortunate to have the resources to invest in this sort of innovation.â  That includes both âthe breadth of our content,â she added, and the sophistication to do a rigorous measure of what works and how well.However, other organizations are already playing in the same sandbox and more will follow. A Digiday story on Project Feels last summer noted that ESPN can target ads depending on whether a given fanâs team is winning or losing. USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window) Comments Comments are closed. I havenât seen an advertisement on the NYT in years, they canât track me and I have all their shenanigans blocked. Funny, how the Poynter person cozily chats with the NYT privacy-buster-in-chief as if itâs a yawner that websites ruthlessly bust privacy and sell personal information, as if itâs all in a dayâs work. Seems to me the âresponsible journalismâ touted here would dictate Poynter inform Little People how to evade the privacy-busters, rather than get us used to the idea we have no privacy leftâ¦ Chris Long April 10, 2019 at 1:18 PM, I am with Next Digital, we are Hong Kong and Taiwanâs largest newspaper/online media group. (feel free to check AC Nielsen, Comscore, Alexa). The journalism being driven by these new subscription techniques is what I call âSubscription Journalismâ. We write for the subscribers. NYT is the best I have seen and knows their prospective subscriber better than most. And we should not be arrogant about this development. Ailes at FOX pioneered then MSNBC followed and CNN is a poor second. In online and Print we have HUFFPOST, VICE, VOX, Daily Beast, and also Daily Caller, Hot Air, Drudge. No one needs to win it all, but rather there needs to be a set niche. NYT with 5 million subscribers lives forever. Yet, lets call it for it what it is. NYT has many disappointed left leaning readers after Mueller, and maybe a few prizes that need to be returned. But do they correct course and move on? I would say no. Stay with what the audience wants, which is trying to deliver Trumpâs scalp. Subscription journalism is the new norm. We write for an audience that will pay. Mark Simon April 10, 2019 at 11:11 PM,

USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window) Comments Comments are closed. I havenât seen an advertisement on the NYT in years, they canât track me and I have all their shenanigans blocked. Funny, how the Poynter person cozily chats with the NYT privacy-buster-in-chief as if itâs a yawner that websites ruthlessly bust privacy and sell personal information, as if itâs all in a dayâs work. Seems to me the âresponsible journalismâ touted here would dictate Poynter inform Little People how to evade the privacy-busters, rather than get us used to the idea we have no privacy leftâ¦ Chris Long April 10, 2019 at 1:18 PM, I am with Next Digital, we are Hong Kong and Taiwanâs largest newspaper/online media group. (feel free to check AC Nielsen, Comscore, Alexa). The journalism being driven by these new subscription techniques is what I call âSubscription Journalismâ. We write for the subscribers. NYT is the best I have seen and knows their prospective subscriber better than most. And we should not be arrogant about this development. Ailes at FOX pioneered then MSNBC followed and CNN is a poor second. In online and Print we have HUFFPOST, VICE, VOX, Daily Beast, and also Daily Caller, Hot Air, Drudge. No one needs to win it all, but rather there needs to be a set niche. NYT with 5 million subscribers lives forever. Yet, lets call it for it what it is. NYT has many disappointed left leaning readers after Mueller, and maybe a few prizes that need to be returned. But do they correct course and move on? I would say no. Stay with what the audience wants, which is trying to deliver Trumpâs scalp. Subscription journalism is the new norm. We write for an audience that will pay. Mark Simon April 10, 2019 at 11:11 PM,

html.textContent: The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel Courtesy New York Times. April 10, 2019 Rick Edmonds Category: Business & Work A year ago, without ceremony, The New York Times piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. âProject Feelsâ has now generated 50 campaigns, more than 30 million impressions and strong revenue results (the Times declines to specify how much).So itâs a hit, and the sort of advertising innovation based on data science, artificial intelligence and algorithm that the Times expects to scale up â and that other news organizations are exploring.To take an example of what the Times more formally is calling âperspective targeting,â  an interview/profile of Cher was determined to put the reader into an inspired, amused and adventurous mood. Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.  Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement.  Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.At a glance this may sound a bit manipulative and âBrave New Worldâ-like to consumers of news.Journalists and other news purists may also wonder whether the Times newsroom is now being tasked with producing lots of emotional stories.Neither is the case, Allison Murphy, senior vice president of advertising innovation, told me in an interview.  The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow. So it has done nothing different. The ad sales initiative  âdoesnât influence what is coveredâ and editorial integrity is not compromised.Allison Murphy. (Courtesy The New York Times)And the âProject Feelsâ ads are actually less intrusive, she argues, since they do not depend on the sort of information about you and your preferences that cookies harvest.Together, Murphy said, the two kinds of âFeelsâ targeting are a match to rising privacy concerns.  They also provide âan original type of brand safetyâ at a time when advertisers need to worry about landing next to objectionable content on platforms like YouTube or Facebook.To date, the most popular advertiser categories have been entertainment and corporate social responsibility messages. The first of the Feels sales was to a story evoking âadventurousâ and aligned with a clientâs launch of a new science fiction series. âSelf-confidentâ was paired with a message centered on womenâs empowerment.  Ads to date have also appeared across 10 other categories.Of the 18 available emotions, 14 are positive.  But even negatives like sadness or indignation, Murphy said, could support a given cause or candidate.  âBoredomâ isnât and wonât be much of a seller. Hereâs the list:Optimistic Inspired Self-Confident Amused Adventurous In the mood to spend Love Sadness Boredom Interest Fear Hate Hope Happiness Nostalgic Indulgent Competitive Informed I asked whether Project Feels might be exported as a franchised service to other news organizations.âGenerally no,â Murphy replied. âThe whole model is based on Times content, and it requires maintenance. â¦ We are very fortunate to have the resources to invest in this sort of innovation.â  That includes both âthe breadth of our content,â she added, and the sophistication to do a rigorous measure of what works and how well.However, other organizations are already playing in the same sandbox and more will follow. A Digiday story on Project Feels last summer noted that ESPN can target ads depending on whether a given fanâs team is winning or losing. USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window) Comments Comments are closed. April 10, 2019 Rick Edmonds Category: Business & Work A year ago, without ceremony, The New York Times piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. âProject Feelsâ has now generated 50 campaigns, more than 30 million impressions and strong revenue results (the Times declines to specify how much).So itâs a hit, and the sort of advertising innovation based on data science, artificial intelligence and algorithm that the Times expects to scale up â and that other news organizations are exploring.To take an example of what the Times more formally is calling âperspective targeting,â  an interview/profile of Cher was determined to put the reader into an inspired, amused and adventurous mood. Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.  Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement.  Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.At a glance this may sound a bit manipulative and âBrave New Worldâ-like to consumers of news.Journalists and other news purists may also wonder whether the Times newsroom is now being tasked with producing lots of emotional stories.Neither is the case, Allison Murphy, senior vice president of advertising innovation, told me in an interview.  The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow. So it has done nothing different. The ad sales initiative  âdoesnât influence what is coveredâ and editorial integrity is not compromised.Allison Murphy. (Courtesy The New York Times)And the âProject Feelsâ ads are actually less intrusive, she argues, since they do not depend on the sort of information about you and your preferences that cookies harvest.Together, Murphy said, the two kinds of âFeelsâ targeting are a match to rising privacy concerns.  They also provide âan original type of brand safetyâ at a time when advertisers need to worry about landing next to objectionable content on platforms like YouTube or Facebook.To date, the most popular advertiser categories have been entertainment and corporate social responsibility messages. The first of the Feels sales was to a story evoking âadventurousâ and aligned with a clientâs launch of a new science fiction series. âSelf-confidentâ was paired with a message centered on womenâs empowerment.  Ads to date have also appeared across 10 other categories.Of the 18 available emotions, 14 are positive.  But even negatives like sadness or indignation, Murphy said, could support a given cause or candidate.  âBoredomâ isnât and wonât be much of a seller. Hereâs the list:Optimistic Inspired Self-Confident Amused Adventurous In the mood to spend Love Sadness Boredom Interest Fear Hate Hope Happiness Nostalgic Indulgent Competitive Informed I asked whether Project Feels might be exported as a franchised service to other news organizations.âGenerally no,â Murphy replied. âThe whole model is based on Times content, and it requires maintenance. â¦ We are very fortunate to have the resources to invest in this sort of innovation.â  That includes both âthe breadth of our content,â she added, and the sophistication to do a rigorous measure of what works and how well.However, other organizations are already playing in the same sandbox and more will follow. A Digiday story on Project Feels last summer noted that ESPN can target ads depending on whether a given fanâs team is winning or losing. USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window) Comments Comments are closed. I havenât seen an advertisement on the NYT in years, they canât track me and I have all their shenanigans blocked. Funny, how the Poynter person cozily chats with the NYT privacy-buster-in-chief as if itâs a yawner that websites ruthlessly bust privacy and sell personal information, as if itâs all in a dayâs work. Seems to me the âresponsible journalismâ touted here would dictate Poynter inform Little People how to evade the privacy-busters, rather than get us used to the idea we have no privacy leftâ¦ Chris Long April 10, 2019 at 1:18 PM, I am with Next Digital, we are Hong Kong and Taiwanâs largest newspaper/online media group. (feel free to check AC Nielsen, Comscore, Alexa). The journalism being driven by these new subscription techniques is what I call âSubscription Journalismâ. We write for the subscribers. NYT is the best I have seen and knows their prospective subscriber better than most. And we should not be arrogant about this development. Ailes at FOX pioneered then MSNBC followed and CNN is a poor second. In online and Print we have HUFFPOST, VICE, VOX, Daily Beast, and also Daily Caller, Hot Air, Drudge. No one needs to win it all, but rather there needs to be a set niche. NYT with 5 million subscribers lives forever. Yet, lets call it for it what it is. NYT has many disappointed left leaning readers after Mueller, and maybe a few prizes that need to be returned. But do they correct course and move on? I would say no. Stay with what the audience wants, which is trying to deliver Trumpâs scalp. Subscription journalism is the new norm. We write for an audience that will pay. Mark Simon April 10, 2019 at 11:11 PM,

html.textContent: The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel Courtesy New York Times. April 10, 2019 Rick Edmonds Category: Business & Work A year ago, without ceremony, The New York Times piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. âProject Feelsâ has now generated 50 campaigns, more than 30 million impressions and strong revenue results (the Times declines to specify how much).So itâs a hit, and the sort of advertising innovation based on data science, artificial intelligence and algorithm that the Times expects to scale up â and that other news organizations are exploring.To take an example of what the Times more formally is calling âperspective targeting,â  an interview/profile of Cher was determined to put the reader into an inspired, amused and adventurous mood. Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.  Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement.  Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.At a glance this may sound a bit manipulative and âBrave New Worldâ-like to consumers of news.Journalists and other news purists may also wonder whether the Times newsroom is now being tasked with producing lots of emotional stories.Neither is the case, Allison Murphy, senior vice president of advertising innovation, told me in an interview.  The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow. So it has done nothing different. The ad sales initiative  âdoesnât influence what is coveredâ and editorial integrity is not compromised.Allison Murphy. (Courtesy The New York Times)And the âProject Feelsâ ads are actually less intrusive, she argues, since they do not depend on the sort of information about you and your preferences that cookies harvest.Together, Murphy said, the two kinds of âFeelsâ targeting are a match to rising privacy concerns.  They also provide âan original type of brand safetyâ at a time when advertisers need to worry about landing next to objectionable content on platforms like YouTube or Facebook.To date, the most popular advertiser categories have been entertainment and corporate social responsibility messages. The first of the Feels sales was to a story evoking âadventurousâ and aligned with a clientâs launch of a new science fiction series. âSelf-confidentâ was paired with a message centered on womenâs empowerment.  Ads to date have also appeared across 10 other categories.Of the 18 available emotions, 14 are positive.  But even negatives like sadness or indignation, Murphy said, could support a given cause or candidate.  âBoredomâ isnât and wonât be much of a seller. Hereâs the list:Optimistic Inspired Self-Confident Amused Adventurous In the mood to spend Love Sadness Boredom Interest Fear Hate Hope Happiness Nostalgic Indulgent Competitive Informed I asked whether Project Feels might be exported as a franchised service to other news organizations.âGenerally no,â Murphy replied. âThe whole model is based on Times content, and it requires maintenance. â¦ We are very fortunate to have the resources to invest in this sort of innovation.â  That includes both âthe breadth of our content,â she added, and the sophistication to do a rigorous measure of what works and how well.However, other organizations are already playing in the same sandbox and more will follow. A Digiday story on Project Feels last summer noted that ESPN can target ads depending on whether a given fanâs team is winning or losing. USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window) Comments Comments are closed. I havenât seen an advertisement on the NYT in years, they canât track me and I have all their shenanigans blocked. Funny, how the Poynter person cozily chats with the NYT privacy-buster-in-chief as if itâs a yawner that websites ruthlessly bust privacy and sell personal information, as if itâs all in a dayâs work. Seems to me the âresponsible journalismâ touted here would dictate Poynter inform Little People how to evade the privacy-busters, rather than get us used to the idea we have no privacy leftâ¦ Chris Long April 10, 2019 at 1:18 PM, I am with Next Digital, we are Hong Kong and Taiwanâs largest newspaper/online media group. (feel free to check AC Nielsen, Comscore, Alexa). The journalism being driven by these new subscription techniques is what I call âSubscription Journalismâ. We write for the subscribers. NYT is the best I have seen and knows their prospective subscriber better than most. And we should not be arrogant about this development. Ailes at FOX pioneered then MSNBC followed and CNN is a poor second. In online and Print we have HUFFPOST, VICE, VOX, Daily Beast, and also Daily Caller, Hot Air, Drudge. No one needs to win it all, but rather there needs to be a set niche. NYT with 5 million subscribers lives forever. Yet, lets call it for it what it is. NYT has many disappointed left leaning readers after Mueller, and maybe a few prizes that need to be returned. But do they correct course and move on? I would say no. Stay with what the audience wants, which is trying to deliver Trumpâs scalp. Subscription journalism is the new norm. We write for an audience that will pay. Mark Simon April 10, 2019 at 11:11 PM,

html.textContent: The New York Times sells premium ads based on how an article makes you feel Courtesy New York Times. April 10, 2019 Rick Edmonds Category: Business & Work A year ago, without ceremony, The New York Times piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. âProject Feelsâ has now generated 50 campaigns, more than 30 million impressions and strong revenue results (the Times declines to specify how much).So itâs a hit, and the sort of advertising innovation based on data science, artificial intelligence and algorithm that the Times expects to scale up â and that other news organizations are exploring.To take an example of what the Times more formally is calling âperspective targeting,â  an interview/profile of Cher was determined to put the reader into an inspired, amused and adventurous mood. Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.  Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement.  Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.At a glance this may sound a bit manipulative and âBrave New Worldâ-like to consumers of news.Journalists and other news purists may also wonder whether the Times newsroom is now being tasked with producing lots of emotional stories.Neither is the case, Allison Murphy, senior vice president of advertising innovation, told me in an interview.  The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow. So it has done nothing different. The ad sales initiative  âdoesnât influence what is coveredâ and editorial integrity is not compromised.Allison Murphy. (Courtesy The New York Times)And the âProject Feelsâ ads are actually less intrusive, she argues, since they do not depend on the sort of information about you and your preferences that cookies harvest.Together, Murphy said, the two kinds of âFeelsâ targeting are a match to rising privacy concerns.  They also provide âan original type of brand safetyâ at a time when advertisers need to worry about landing next to objectionable content on platforms like YouTube or Facebook.To date, the most popular advertiser categories have been entertainment and corporate social responsibility messages. The first of the Feels sales was to a story evoking âadventurousâ and aligned with a clientâs launch of a new science fiction series. âSelf-confidentâ was paired with a message centered on womenâs empowerment.  Ads to date have also appeared across 10 other categories.Of the 18 available emotions, 14 are positive.  But even negatives like sadness or indignation, Murphy said, could support a given cause or candidate.  âBoredomâ isnât and wonât be much of a seller. Hereâs the list:Optimistic Inspired Self-Confident Amused Adventurous In the mood to spend Love Sadness Boredom Interest Fear Hate Hope Happiness Nostalgic Indulgent Competitive Informed I asked whether Project Feels might be exported as a franchised service to other news organizations.âGenerally no,â Murphy replied. âThe whole model is based on Times content, and it requires maintenance. â¦ We are very fortunate to have the resources to invest in this sort of innovation.â  That includes both âthe breadth of our content,â she added, and the sophistication to do a rigorous measure of what works and how well.However, other organizations are already playing in the same sandbox and more will follow. A Digiday story on Project Feels last summer noted that ESPN can target ads depending on whether a given fanâs team is winning or losing. USA Today has a version called Lens Targeting with stories graded on the mood likely to be evoked.As Murphyâs job title suggests, perspective targeting is not a one-off but part of a series of innovation projects. She was involved in the development of Flex Frames, a premium full-screen display that works on any device. Next she is planning a variant of Feels to get at motivation.More broadly, the industry has been seeing data analysis generating models that can match story choices to a target audienceâs greatest âpassion topicsâ or can guide strategy for digital subscription paywalls and pricing. I am not saying emotional targeting and its algorithmic cousins are the Holy Grail of a new business model â but they canât hurt.Share this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Linked In (Opens in new window)Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)

Should those feelings be a fit to an advertiserâs pitch, a placement automatically drops into the digital edition of the story.
html.nouns: example Times âperspective targeting,â interview/profile of Cher reader mood.  feelings advertiserâs pitch, placement edition of the story.

html.textContent: Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.
Unlike those ads that stalk you across the internet based on what you have read and looked at, the connection will typically be invisible to the reader.
Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:
Here is how the futuristic-sounding product was developed and how it works:

The Times began by asking a volunteer group of readers to choose from a list of 18 emotions that they felt as they read a sample of Times stories.With 150,000 data points, an analysis team could identify articles with strong emotional resonance. The resulting algorithm then instantly finds which combination of emotions is evoked as the story is posted.The Times and its advertisers can track with some precision whether the ad outperforms a more random placement. Some have generated as much as 80 percent more impressions than regular behavioral targeting. The average lift is 40 percent. That success supports a premium charge.The offering also includes âneutrality targetingâ: that is, isolating upsetting stories that could decrease receptivity to ad messages â placements to be avoided.

html.textContent: I am with Next Digital, we are Hong Kong and Taiwanâs largest newspaper/online media group.  (feel free to check AC Nielsen, Comscore, Alexa).  The journalism being driven by these new subscription techniques is what I call âSubscription Journalismâ.  We write for the subscribers.  NYT is the best I have seen and knows their prospective subscriber better than most.  And we should not be arrogant about this development.  Ailes at FOX pioneered then MSNBC followed and CNN is a poor second.  In online and Print we have HUFFPOST, VICE, VOX, Daily Beast, and also Daily Caller, Hot Air, Drudge.   No one needs to win it all, but rather there needs to be a set niche.  NYT with 5 million subscribers lives forever.   Yet, lets call it for it what it is.  NYT has many disappointed left leaning readers after Mueller, and maybe a few prizes that need to be returned.  But do they correct course and move on?  I would say no.  Stay with what the audience wants, which is trying to deliver Trumpâs scalp. Subscription journalism is the new norm.  We write for an audience that will pay.                                                                                                            Mark Simon                                                    April 10, 2019 at 11:11 PM,
